awd_titl_txt: CICI: RSARC: DICE - Data Insurance in the Cluster Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
High-performance, distributed computing has become indispensable in solving complex scientific, engineering, and business problems. The integrity of the data generated and stored on computer clusters is of undisputed importance to scientific research and business intelligence, as compromised data can lead to incorrect conclusions and decisions. Unfortunately, existing security mechanisms for high-performance and distributed computing systems are complex, inconsistent, insecure, and difficult to deploy. Many systems utilizing the current security mechanisms simply do not provide sufficient protection and remain vulnerable to even trivial attacks. For example, recent studies have found that thousands of unprotected database installations and computer clusters have been hacked. As such, there is a pressing need to improve the security of high-performance and distributed computing systems. 

This project develops a security framework for high-performance and distributed computing systems that employs strong modern cryptographic algorithms, and is easy to reason, deploy, and use without lengthy and error-prone configurations.  The project consists of three major components: a container-based virtual cluster, a component to defend against side-channel attacks, and a secure execution ledger for auditing. The first component is the key to enabling authentication, authorization, and data protection for clusters without sacrificing usability or performance. The project team will build the virtual cluster based on the popular Docker container but enhance it with flexible key management, attack surface reduction, and security hardening, including defenses against side-channel attacks. Communications among nodes of a virtual cluster and I/O operations are transparently encrypted to protect the data in transition and at rest. The secure execution ledger provides a global holistic view of program execution in the whole system, allowing auditing the behavior of individual users as well as user groups. By tightly integrating these three components, the project seeks to achieve strong support for the four pillars of the cluster data security ? authentication, authorization, auditing, and data protection.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims at enhancing the security in High Performance Computing (HPC) and distributed computing clusters. The major research and development outcomes of this project include the development of CryptMPI, an efficient secure Message Passing Library (MPI) library, and QuickLog, a fast and secure logging system. The software for both CryptMPI and QuickLog have been released in the public domain.

MPI, the de facto standard for developing message passing program in high performance computing, has been widely used. MPI applications have been enabling discovery in many math, science, technology, and engineering fields. CryptMPI helps secure communications in MPI applications in the cluster environment. To achieve high performance, a range of techniques have been developed and incorporated in CryptMPI, including novel algorithms for collective communications, overlapping communication with computation, pipelined communication, pre-calculation, and multi-threading. These techniques advance the state-of-the-art for supporting efficient secure MPI communications. One unique feature of CryptMPI is that it does not require any special hardware support and can be deployed in existing systems. CryptMPI should help the porting of MPI applications to the cloud computing environment.

 System logging is the basic mechanism for defending against cybersecurity attacks. QuickLog that we develop in this project pushes the limit of the state-of-the-art secure logging system by employing a novel use of cryptographic techniques and exploiting the hardware support for cryptographic operations. With QuickLog, secure logging can be performed efficiently while be sanctioned by the standard agency (e.g. NIST), allowing QuickLog to be adopted by government agencies and the industry.

Based on the research in this project, we have developed several projects and education modules for various courses. We have developed an education module on the streaming encryption that we used in CryptMPI for CIS5371 Cryptography, a graduate class. The module has been taught in Fall 2020.  A module on algorithm issues for MPI collective communications has been developed and taught in the Spring 2022 offering of CDA5125 Parallel and Distributed Systems. Additionally, a course project on defending against side-channel attacks and another one on MPI collective communication implementation have been developed and assigned to students in CDA5125.

Six PhD students and two undergraduate students have participated in this project. The PhD students have been trained to be experts in the joint field of High Performance Computing, Cybersecurity, and Computer Systems. Two PhDs students have defended their dissertations, another two are in their final year of PhD study.
